Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 04:15PM Dulcigirl wrote: Oh, Stephanie, I'm SO sorry you find yourself faced with all of these decisions and worries. This site is such a great place for support and info! I would encourage you that once you have your surgery date you should join the group for surgeries in that month. You'll also want to join the reconstruction threads for whichever procedure you end up going with. I can't answer all of your questions. I can just share my own experience. When I met my surgeon to discuss my options she immediately told me that I would only be a candidate for implant reconstruction as I was too thin to have enough tissue to make two breasts. Be prepared for that. Also know that your particular surgeon may have a preference. Not all surgeons do all types of recon. you may have to shop around for a surgeon who can do the type you want, but be very sure he/she has a lot of experience performing that type of recon. I had my BMX and tissue expanders were placed at the same time. I do not think I drove for 4-5 weeks. It took a couple of weeks before I could get out of bed or out of the recliner without help or loads of pain. I gradually got stronger and also gradually got the anesthesia out of my system. It took about 6 weeks to really feel like myself again. Meanwhile my tissue expanders were being filled. I didn't have much trouble with that process, but I did have to sleep sitting upright in our recliner for 3-4 months. I had my exchange to implants in February. My silicone round mplants look quite natural. I'm pleased with the shape and feel of them. Two weeks ago I had a revision to smaller, different styled implants. I feel much better with these and am ready to move on. In a few months I will get reconstructed nipples and then a few months after that I will have areola tattoos. If things go as planned I will be done about 1.5 years after I started. Candidates for nipple sparing will not take as long I'm guessing. I chose not to keep mine. I think what you need to know is that it can be a lengthy process even if all goes smoothly. I do not know how differently a completely prophylactic experience will be. Hopefully some ladies can chime in on that one! Keep asking questions and keep reading here! Explore the different recon threads, but do keep in mind that there is a greater percentage of "problems" posted. Many women that have positive experiences don't hang out on the boards. So please don't assume that everyone has a negative experience! But it is good to know the risks. I wish you all the best! It's not an easy thing, but there are LOTS of women walking around us every day that have been here, done that, got the t-shirt and are still smiling!!!! Hugs to you!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 07:39AM - edited Nov 24, 2013 07:39AM by Dulcigirl I love biking. I mainly ride Rails-to-Trails...so some rough spots, mainly gravel/crushed limestone/dirt. My first exchange ended up being too big. I rode through the summer with those in. Totally doable! I realize what you do is more strenuous. I just had a revision to smaller implants and LOVE them. The only issues I had with biking is that if I gripped extra hard or only had one hand on the bars my pec contracted and felt kind of weird. Still doable!! But that issue has gotten better too with the smaller size. I know with mtn biking you have more more weight on the bars, so the pec thing might be a bit more of an issue. But it never has hurt, just feels a bit odd. And you may want to try to stay close to your current size just so stuff doesn't get in your way. ;-) Of course all of my experience only applies to my type of recon. I did bmx to TE's to implants. I did not ride during my TE phase as it happened to be over the winter.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2013 04:17AM Dulcigirl wrote: Another thought I had regarding the "tiny scar" comment: I was with my mom when she had her first diagnosis and mastectomy 26 years ago. That surgery was done by a general surgeon. Mom did not have reconstruction. Went through my mom's second diagnosis and mastectomy about 8 years ago. Again, no recon. The cosmetic difference between those two surgeries was quite vast. And then my own BMX this past fall, performed by a good breast surgeon and closed by my PS after he placed TE's.... My scars, though the line goes from near my armpit, across each breast probably 3/4's of the way ARE tiny in comparison to my mom's first surgery. Angelina's nipple sparing scars would be even smaller/less noticeable. I do not know when her mother had her mastectomies, but the comparison to what she saw on HER mom quite possibly matches my experience. When I chose to go with a double mastectomy following a very early IDC catch, I chose so with the image of my mom's first surgery results. I have been pleasantly surprised by my results. Not perfect, not the real thing, not something I would wish on anyone.....but vastly better than what I had anticipated.

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2012 05:42AM Dulcigirl wrote: I'm laughing now too, because just last night i was wondering where my nipples ended up. I'm assuming they went to pathology before the garbage truck backed up....beep, beep, beep...... I explained the lack of nipples/aereola to my college girlfriends. They got quiet and I said, "Hey!! It's worked for Barbie for longer than I've been alive!" I can't laugh all day and I still have many moments of crying, but the moments of laughter are good!! Reminds me of a verse in a song I like. "There may be pain in the night, but joy comes in the morning!" My doctor had the radioactive tracer done about an hour and a half prior to my BMX. First the radiologist injected some numbing thing. It's interesting how there are so many ways to do the same thing. Hoping this morning brings you all some moments of joy....be watching for them! Sometimes you have to wipe some tears away before you can see them.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 04:40AM Dulcigirl wrote: Ok. I have one of those "is this happening to you?" Kinds of questions. In two days it will be 3 weeks since my BMX/TE surgery. I'm improving, but there is one really annoying thing that doesn't seem to be changing and it was extra bad during the very long road trip we just took. All across my breast area the skin just feels raw. It ISN'T!!! (I keep checking.) it's worst on the top half. Riding in the car seemed to make it feel worse due to the friction of my VERY soft shirt rubbing on my skin more than it does if I'm just sitting in the recliner. (But I got to see my son graduate!! Yay!!) Is this from the nerve damage from surgery? Any guesses if it will ever stop or get better? Any tips/tricks to minimize the burning feeling that sometimes makes it hard to sleep? At first I really thought it was my super sensitive skin reacting to tape, etc, but now I'm realizing it is not on the surface. It feels uncomfortable to touch the skin, too, but there is no redness, rash, dryness, etc. so I believe it's nerves underneath. I guess I'm hoping somebody has a recommendation for some lovely smelling lotion or cream that would make it stop!!!!! Lol. If not that, I'd just love to hear a "yep. Me too!" so I'll know I'm not alone. No wait. That wasn't nice!! I'd rather nobody else was feeling this! Sooooo....how about just a good 'ole "I had it for a week then it went away." ;-) Funny, too, because my husband accidentally elbowed my left one the other day and I didn't feel that. Weird foobies!!!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2012 08:44AM Dulcigirl wrote: Connie!!! Sorry you are having a freaking out moment!!!! (((((Hug!))))) Take a deep breath and remember how far you've already come...ONE STEP AT A TIME!! My BS told me NOT to google in general, but that THIS site had good information if I really felt the need to search. If you are feeling like you must search I would read the information parts of the site before you get stuck in message board land. I know how overwhelmingly supportive the message board has been for both of us, BUT we each have our own story and our own diagnosis, so panicking because of what someone else has faced/is facing doesn't make sense, right???? I don't know the scientific answers to help you. I know my BS said my ER+/PR+, HER2- is the best case scenario, so it's the HER2+ that is the difference between ours. If you're needing to start researching I would start there. But I would also ONLY do it to give you good questions for the oncologist. He/she will be able to tell you what it all means based on YOUR special story. Praying for your PEACE right now as you wait for your appointment and I'm so sorry you're going through this today! It's such a very cold day here in MI! I hope you can snuggle up with your kiddos and some cocoa and enjoy being together.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 08:52PM Dulcigirl wrote: I also have Meniere's and am just extra sensative to ALL meds. I have not had any trouble with dizziness or sickness with anesthesia. I usually just feel like I'm slowly trying to wake up. Last time was the hardest...the first thing I remember hearing was the nurse telling me to wake up, take another deep breath, etc. But never any sickness....just a bit of time to fully wake up and a gradual return to alertness. Express your concerns to your anesthesiologist. It's his/her job to give you just the right thing for you. Best wishes!

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 01:53PM Dulcigirl wrote: I was diagnosed Sept 12 and had my BMX Oct 16. That allowed my BS and PS to coordinate so that they worked together and my reconstruction process started immediately after my BS finished her part of the operation.Â  You will get more info at your appointment. There is a great section here on bco that gives a suggested list of questions to ask your doctor.Â  It will feel like forever and it will also feel like it goes too quickly! It's a great idea to start a binder and keep copies of test results, notes, business cards, etc. I think we all have that fear that you are feeling while waiting. I know I sure did! But take a deep breath and know that you do have some time to think, ask questions, make plans,...
Posts.Title: Wait time between diagnosis and surgery katiegrey Pupcake

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 09:00AM Dulcigirl wrote: I really believed that someone told me never to use antiperspirant again during my discharge instructions the morning after my BMX. I was a bit foggy at the time. DH doesn't remember it. I tried a few different deodorants and finally settled on a grapefruit one by LaVanilla. For the first couple of weeks I used nothing and couldn't stand the smell. The LaVanilla helped with the smell, but I had to stop wearing some of the shirts I normally wore to work because I would get big sweat spots. 3 months went by and I went for my pre-exchange visit with my PS. I asked him if the "no antiperspirant" thing was forever or just while healing. I really thought he was the one who told me to stop using it! He said he would NEVER say such a thing and that as much as we go through he would never take away something like hygiene that would make us feel worse. So, I have NO idea WHO told me that or if I dreamed the whole thing up while medicated. What were you all told? My BS was able to do my SNB through my mastectomy incision so I did not have an extra incision to heal in my armpit...though it was very sore. She said one ended up being further in than it had appeared so she had to "do some digging" to get it. Shudder. Thanks!! For now I'm sticking with my natural LaVanilla just because it feels good. But I'm reserving my anti-p for special occasions.
Posts.Title: YUCK! How to tame the Armpit BO Monster - Suggestions? Janipani Alive4Five

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 06:39AM Dulcigirl wrote: Randie, Your doctor should tell you if it is IDC (invasive ductal carcinoma) or DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ). Treatment plans/options for the two can be different. Take a deep breath and try to see him for a complete explanation before you panic. Do you have a breast surgeon? If not, find a good one soon. THAT is where I got my best info. Hang in there!! You can do this! English Teacher: so sorry you've had to join us, but as you learn to navigate through the threads you'll be amazed at the wealth of info, love and support. One of the most important things I learned was that although I wanted to do something RIGHT NOW, it just doesn't work that quickly....but that is ok! You have time to get informed, find a dr you trust and make the treatment decisions that are best for you!!

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 10:16AM Dulcigirl wrote: Thank you for this post and reply. My BMX with TE's is one week from tomorrow. I too have gotten lost in this overwhelmingly supportive ton of threads. Yesterday I picked up one of those cushion/pillow things that helps you stay upright (to read) in bed. NO IDEA what the official name for it is, but it seems to cradle me nicely and also act as the foundation of a wall to keep DH from an accidental snuggle. Yikes. I've also got comfy button up pj's for home, stool softener, a battery powered toothbrush, a pack of headbands because I'm sure the curling iron is out for a while, some baby wipes for freshening up if the shower seems like too much for a while, and rubber gloves/alcohol wipes for the drains. Tomorrow I'm going to our hospital med equipment place to be fitted for a recovery cami my doctor prescribed. Yesterday I stopped and got a couple of loose button down shirts and a couple of hoodies for whenever I venture out of the house again. And had a meltdown in the dressing room while trying them on. I've accepted this and am ready to move forward, but there are moments when it's all just very overwhelming!!! Connie, I'll try to notice anything I'd wished I had and write here before you go! (If I can find this thread again!!! Lol.)
